cleaned_text: Waldorf education Waldorf education, also known as Steiner education, is based on the [educational philosophy](/wiki/Educational_philosophy) of [Rudolf Steiner](/wiki/Rudolf_Steiner), the founder of [anthroposophy](/wiki/Anthroposophy). Its educational style is [holistic](/wiki/Holistic_education), intended to develop pupils' intellectual, artistic, and practical skills, with a focus on imagination and creativity. Individual teachers have a great deal of autonomy in curriculum content, teaching methods, and governance. [Qualitative assessments](/wiki/Formative_assessments) of student work are integrated into the daily life of the classroom, with [standardized testing](/wiki/Standardized_testing) limited to what is required to enter [post-secondary education](/wiki/Higher_education). The first Waldorf school opened in 1919 in [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart), Germany. [[1]](#cite_note-1) A century later, it has become the largest independent school movement in the world, [[2]](#cite_note-Zdrazil2018-2) with more than 1,200 independent schools and nearly 2,000 kindergartens in 75 countries, [[3]](#cite_note-schulliste-3) as well as more than 500 centers for [special education](/wiki/Special_education) in more than 40 countries. [[4]](#cite_note-4) Waldorf-based [public schools](/wiki/Public_education), [Germany](/wiki/Germany), the [United States](/wiki/United_States), and the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands) have the most Waldorf schools. [[3]](#cite_note-schulliste-3) Many Waldorf schools have faced controversy due to [Steiner's connections to racist ideology](/wiki/Rudolf_Steiner_and_race) and [magical thinking](/wiki/Magical_thinking). Others have faced regulatory audits and closure due to concerns over substandard treatment of special needs children. Critics of Waldorf education (e.g., Roger Rawlings) point out the mystical nature of anthroposophy and the incorporation of Steiner's esoteric ideas into the curriculum. [[7]](#cite_note-Quackwatch-7) [[8]](#cite_note-8) Waldorf schools have also been linked to the outbreak of infectious diseases due to the vaccine hesitancy of many Waldorf parents. [[9]](#cite_note-9) [[10]](#cite_note-10) [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=1)] The first school based upon the ideas of Rudolf Steiner was opened in 1919 in response to a request from [Emil Molt](/wiki/Emil_Molt), owner and managing director of the [Waldorf-Astoria Cigarette Company](/wiki/Waldorf-Astoria-Zigarettenfabrik) in [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart), Germany. This is the source of the name Waldorf, which is now trademarked in the United States when used in connection with the educational method. [[14]](#cite_note-14) Molt's proposed school would educate the children of employees of the factory. [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15): 381 Molt was a follower of [anthroposophy](/wiki/Anthroposophy), an [esoteric](/wiki/Western_esotericism) spiritual movement based on the notion that an objectively comprehensible spiritual realm exists and can be observed by humans, and of Rudolf Steiner, the movement's founder and spiritual leader. [[16]](#cite_note-16) Many of Steiner's ideas influenced the pedagogy of the original Waldorf school and still play a central role in modern Waldorf classrooms: reincarnation, [[17]](#cite_note-17) karma, [[18]](#cite_note-18) [[19]](#cite_note-19) the existence of spiritual beings, [[20]](#cite_note-20) [[21]](#cite_note-21) the idea that children are themselves spiritual beings, [[22]](#cite_note-WoodsSpiritualValues-22) and [eurythmy](/wiki/Eurythmy). [[23]](#cite_note-23) As the co-educational school also served children from outside the factory, it included children from a diverse social spectrum. It was also the first [comprehensive school](/wiki/Comprehensive_school) in Germany, serving children of all genders, abilities, and social classes. [[24]](#cite_note-Hemleben-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) [[26]](#cite_note-Barnes-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) Waldorf education became more widely known in 1922 through lectures Steiner gave at a conference at [Oxford University](/wiki/Oxford_University). [[28]](#cite_note-28) Two years later, on his final trip to Britain at [Torquay](/wiki/Torquay) in 1924, Steiner delivered a Waldorf teacher training course. [[29]](#cite_note-Torquay-29) The first school in England ( [Michael Hall](/wiki/Michael_Hall_(school))) was founded in 1925; the first in the United States (the Rudolf Steiner School in New York City) in 1928. By the 1930s, numerous schools inspired by Steiner's pedagogical principles had opened in Germany, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Norway, Austria, Hungary, the United States, and England. [[30]](#cite_note-30) From 1933 to 1945, political interference from the [Nazi](/wiki/Nazi) regime limited and ultimately closed most Waldorf schools in Europe, with the exception of some British, Swiss, and Dutch schools (UK and Switzerland did not get occupied by Nazi Germany). [Rudolf Hess](/wiki/Rudolf_Hess), the adjunct Führer, was a patron of Waldorf schools. [[31]](#cite_note-Douglas-Hamilton_2012_p._106-31) [[32]](#cite_note-Rieppel_2016_p._246-32) The affected schools reopened after the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War) ended. [[33]](#cite_note-Uncommon-33) A few schools elsewhere in Europe (e.g. in Norway) survived by going underground. [[34]](#cite_note-34) Some schools in [East Germany](/wiki/East_Germany) were re-closed a few years later by the [Communist](/wiki/Communism) [government](/wiki/Politics_of_East_Germany). [[35]](#cite_note-35) In North America in 1967, there were nine schools in the United States and one in Canada. [[36]](#cite_note-36) [[37]](#cite_note-37) As of 2021, that number had increased to more than 200 in the United States and over 20 in Canada. [[3]](#cite_note-schulliste-3) [[38]](#cite_note-charters-38) [[39]](#cite_note-NYT-39) [[40]](#cite_note-40) There are currently 29 Steiner schools in the United Kingdom and three in the [Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland). [[41]](#cite_note-41) After the [dissolution of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union), Waldorf schools again began to proliferate in [Central and Eastern Europe](/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe). More recently, many have opened in Asia, especially China. [[42]](#cite_note-42) [[43]](#cite_note-43) There are currently over 1,200 independent Waldorf schools worldwide. [[3]](#cite_note-schulliste-3) Developmental approach[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=2)] The structure of Waldorf education follows a theory of [childhood development](/wiki/Child_development) devised by Rudolf Steiner, utilizing distinct learning strategies for each of three developmental stages or "epochs": [[44]](#cite_note-SteinerEpochs-44) [[45]](#cite_note-WilkinsonIntro-45) early childhood, elementary, and secondary education. [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15) [[46]](#cite_note-BBC-46) [[47]](#cite_note-Ph.D.2006-47) Steiner believed each [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-49) [[50]](#cite_note-50) [[51]](#cite_note-51) [[52]](#cite_note-52) Aside from their spiritual underpinnings, Steiner's seven-year stages are broadly similar to those later described by [Jean Piaget](/wiki/Jean_Piaget) and also theories described earlier by [Comenius](/wiki/Comenius) and [Pestalozzi](/wiki/Johann_Heinrich_Pestalozzi). [[53]](#cite_note-Ullrich-53) [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15): 402 [[54]](#cite_note-IHG-54) The stated purpose of this approach is to awaken the "physical, behavioral, emotional, cognitive, social, and spiritual" aspects of each pupil. [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55) Early childhood[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=3)] In Waldorf pedagogy, young children learn best through immersion in un-selfconscious imitation of practical activities. The early childhood curriculum focuses on [experiential education](/wiki/Experiential_education) and imaginative play. [[56]](#cite_note-PBU-56) [[57]](#cite_note-57) [[58]](#cite_note-TheAtlantic-58) [[59]](#cite_note-ParkerRees-59) The overall goal of the curriculum is to "imbue the child with a sense that the world is good". [[60]](#cite_note-UllrichRS-60) Waldorf [preschools](/wiki/Preschool) employ a regular daily routine that includes free play, artistic work (e.g. drawing, painting or modeling), [circle time](/wiki/Circle_time) (songs, games, and stories), outdoor recess, [[60]](#cite_note-UllrichRS-60): 125 and practical tasks (e.g. cooking, cleaning, and gardening), with rhythmic variations. [[61]](#cite_note-61) Rhythm and repetitive patterns are considered important in anthroposophy and are believed to hold spiritual significance. [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15) [[62]](#cite_note-62) The classroom is intended to resemble a home, with tools and toys usually sourced from simple, natural materials that lend themselves to imaginative play. [[63]](#cite_note-Edwards-63) The use of natural materials has been praised as fulfilling children's aesthetic needs and reinforcing connections to nature, [[63]](#cite_note-Edwards-63) [[64]](#cite_note-64) [[65]](#cite_note-65) [[66]](#cite_note-66) though some scholars have questioned whether the preference for natural, non-manufactured materials is truly a "reasoned assessment of twenty-first century children's needs", rather than "a reaction against the dehumanizing aspects of nineteenth-century industrialization". [[67]](#cite_note-Siraj-BlatchfordWhitebread2003-67) Pre-school and kindergarten programs generally include seasonal festivals drawn from a variety of traditions, with attention placed on traditions brought forth from the surrounding community. [[68]](#cite_note-68) Waldorf schools in the [Western Hemisphere](/wiki/Western_Hemisphere) have traditionally celebrated Christian festivals, [[69]](#cite_note-IO-69) though one source states that some North American Waldorf schools also include Jewish holidays. [[70]](#cite_note-70) Waldorf kindergarten and lower grades generally discourage pupils' use of electronic media such as television and computers. [[58]](#cite_note-TheAtlantic-58) There are a variety of reasons for this: Waldorf educators believe that use of these conflicts with young children's developmental needs, [[71]](#cite_note-woods_forum-71) media users may be physically inactive, and media may be seen to contain inappropriate or undesirable content and to hamper the imagination. [[72]](#cite_note-Thomas-72) Elementary education[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=4)] Waldorf pedagogues consider that [readiness for learning to read](/wiki/Learning_to_read#Age_to_introduce_literacy_learning) depends upon increased independence of character, temperament, habits, and memory, one of the markers of which is the loss of the baby teeth. [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15): 389 [[53]](#cite_note-Ullrich-53) [[73]](#cite_note-73) Formal instruction in reading, writing, and other academic disciplines are therefore not introduced until students enter the elementary school, when pupils are around seven years of age. [[74]](#cite_note-74) Steiner believed that engaging young children in abstract intellectual activity too early would adversely affect their growth and development. [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15): 389 Waldorf elementary schools (ages 7-14) emphasize cultivating children's emotional life and imagination. In order that students can connect more deeply with the subject matter, academic instruction is presented through artistic work that includes story-telling, [visual arts](/wiki/Visual_arts), drama, movement, music, and crafts. [[75]](#cite_note-Nielsen2004-75) [[76]](#cite_note-CPE-76) [[77]](#cite_note-FE-77) The core curriculum includes language arts, mythology, history, geography, geology, algebra, geometry, mineralogy, biology, astronomy, physics, chemistry, and nutrition. [[60]](#cite_note-UllrichRS-60) The school day generally begins with a one-and-a-half to two-hour, cognitively oriented academic lesson, or " [Main lesson](/wiki/Main_lesson)", that focuses on a single theme over one month's time. [[60]](#cite_note-UllrichRS-60): 145 This typically begins with introductory activities that may include singing, instrumental music, and recitations of poetry, generally including a verse written by Rudolf Steiner for the start of a school day. [[69]](#cite_note-IO-69) There is little reliance on standardized textbooks. [[53]](#cite_note-Ullrich-53) Waldorf elementary education allows for individual variations in the pace of learning, based upon the expectation that a child will grasp a concept or achieve a skill when he or she is ready. [[33]](#cite_note-Uncommon-33) Cooperation takes priority over competition. [[78]](#cite_note-McDermott_etal-78) This approach also extends to physical education; competitive team sports are not introduced until upper grades. [[58]](#cite_note-TheAtlantic-58) Each class remains together as a [cohort](/wiki/Cohort_(educational_group)) throughout all elementary, developing as a quasi-familial social group. [[79]](#cite_note-Ashley-79) In elementary years, a core teacher teaches primary academic subjects. A central role of this teacher is to provide a supportive [role model](/wiki/Role_model) both through personal example and through stories drawn from a variety of cultures, [[60]](#cite_note-UllrichRS-60) educating by exercising "creative, loving authority". [[80]](#cite_note-80) Class teachers are normally expected to teach a cohort for several years, [[81]](#cite_note-Frink-81) a practice known as [looping](/wiki/Looping_(education)). Starting in first grade, specialized teachers teach many subjects, including music, crafts, movement, and two foreign languages from complementary language families [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15) (in English-speaking countries these are typically German and either Spanish or French). While class teachers serve a valuable role as personal mentors, establishing "lasting relationships with pupils", [[81]](#cite_note-Frink-81) Ullrich documented problems when the same teacher continues into [middle school](/wiki/Middle_school). Noting that there is a danger of any [authority figure](/wiki/Authority_figure) limiting students enthusiasm for [inquiry](/wiki/Inquiry) and [autonomy](/wiki/Autonomy), he cited a number of schools where the class teacher accompanies the class for six years only, after which specialist teachers play a greater role. [[60]](#cite_note-UllrichRS-60): 222 Four temperaments[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=5)] Steiner considered children's cognitive, emotional, and behavioral development to be interlinked. [[82]](#cite_note-82) When students in a Waldorf school are grouped, it is generally not by a focus on academic abilities. [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 89 Instead, Steiner adapted the pseudoscientific proto-psychological and choleric. [[83]](#cite_note-grant1999-83) Steiner indicated that teaching should be differentiated to accommodate the different needs that these "types" represent. [[84]](#cite_note-autogenerated4-84) For example, Anthroposophists believe "cholerics are risk takers, phlegmatics take things calmly, melancholics are sensitive or introverted, and sanguines take things lightly". [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 18 Steiner also believed that teachers must consider their own temperament and be prepared to work with it positively in the classroom, [[85]](#cite_note-Stehlik-85) that temperament is emergent in children, [[33]](#cite_note-Uncommon-33) and that most people express a combination of temperaments rather than a pure single type. [[83]](#cite_note-grant1999-83) No evidence exists for such "personality types" to be consistent in an individual across time or context, [[86]](#cite_note-SciencePseudosciencePersonality-86) [[87]](#cite_note-Discover-87) nor that such "types" are useful in providing more effective education. [[88]](#cite_note-NeuroscienceinEducation-88) [[89]](#cite_note-CriticalReviewLearning-89) [[90]](#cite_note-PrevalenceofPseudoscienceLearning-90) Today, Waldorf teachers may work with these pseudoscientific "temperaments" to design instruction for each student. Seating arrangements and class activities may take into account the supposed temperaments of students but this is often not described to parents, students, or observers. [[91]](#cite_note-Whedon2007-91) [[92]](#cite_note-92) Secondary education[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=6)] In most Waldorf schools, pupils enter secondary education when they are fourteen years old. Secondary education is provided by specialist teachers for each subject. The curriculum is purported to foster pupils' intellectual understanding, independent judgment, and ethics. [[56]](#cite_note-PBU-56) [[63]](#cite_note-Edwards-63) In the third developmental stage (14 years old and up), children are supposed to learn through their own thinking and judgment. [[93]](#cite_note-93) Students are asked to understand abstract material and expected to have sufficient foundation and maturity to form conclusions using their own judgment. [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15): 391 The overarching goals are to provide young people the basis on which to develop into [free](/wiki/Freedom_(philosophy)), [morally responsible](/wiki/Morality), [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55) [[94]](#cite_note-94) and creative beings. [[95]](#cite_note-95) No independent studies have been published as to whether or not Waldorf education achieves these aims more than any other approach. [[79]](#cite_note-Ashley-79) Educational theory and practice[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=7)] The philosophical foundation of the Waldorf approach, [anthroposophy](/wiki/Anthroposophy), underpins its primary pedagogical goals: to provide an education that enables children to become free human beings, and to help children to incarnate their "unfolding spiritual identity", carried from the preceding spiritual existence, as beings of body, soul, and spirit in this lifetime. [[96]](#cite_note-Miller-96) Educational researcher Martin Ashley suggests that the latter role would be problematic for secular teachers and parents in state schools, [[79]](#cite_note-Ashley-79) and the commitment to a spiritual background both of the child and the education has been problematic for some committed to a secular perspective. [[39]](#cite_note-NYT-39) [[79]](#cite_note-Ashley-79) [[97]](#cite_note-SF-97) While anthroposophy underpins the curriculum design, pedagogical approach, and organizational structure, it is explicitly not taught within the school curriculum and studies have shown that Waldorf pupils have little awareness of it. [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 6 Tensions may arise within the Waldorf community between the commitment to Steiner's original intentions and openness to new directions in education, such as the incorporation of new technologies or modern methods of accountability and assessment. [[79]](#cite_note-Ashley-79) Waldorf schools frequently have striking architecture, employing walls meeting at varied angles (not only perpendicularly). The walls are often painted in subtle colors, often with a lazure technique, and include textured surfaces. [[98]](#cite_note-Krogh-98) Assessment[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=8)] The schools primarily assess students through reports on individual academic progress and personal development. The emphasis is on characterization through qualitative description. Pupils' progress is evaluated through portfolio work in academic blocks and discussion of pupils in teacher conferences. Standardized tests are rare, with the exception of examinations necessary for college entry taken during secondary school years. [[60]](#cite_note-UllrichRS-60): 150, 186 [Letter grades](/wiki/Grading_in_education) are generally not given until students enter high school. [[99]](#cite_note-99) Pupils are not typically asked to repeat years of elementary or secondary education. [[100]](#cite_note-100) Curriculum[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=9)] Though Waldorf schools are autonomous institutions not required to follow a prescribed curriculum (beyond what is required by local governments) there are widely agreed upon guidelines for the Waldorf curriculum. [[71]](#cite_note-woods_forum-71) Main academic subjects are introduced through two-hour morning lesson blocks that last for several weeks. [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 18 These blocks are horizontally integrated at each grade level in that the topic of the block will be infused into many classroom activities and vertically integrated in that each subject will be revisited with increasing complexity as students develop their skills, reasoning capacities and individual sense of self. This has been described as a spiral curriculum. [[101]](#cite_note-101) Many subjects and skills not considered core parts of mainstream schools, such as art, music, gardening, and mythology, are central to Waldorf education. [[102]](#cite_note-102) Students learn a variety of fine and practical arts. Elementary students paint, draw, sculpt, knit, weave, and crochet. [[103]](#cite_note-103) Older students build on these experiences and learn new skills such as pattern-making and sewing, wood and stone carving, metal work, book-binding, [[104]](#cite_note-104) and doll or puppet making. Music instruction begins with singing in early childhood and continuing through high school. Pupils also usually learn to play [pentatonic](/wiki/Pentatonic_scale) flutes, [recorders](/wiki/Recorder_(musical_instrument)) and/or [lyres](/wiki/Lyre) in early elementary grades. Around age 9, [diatonic](/wiki/Diatonic) recorders and orchestral instruments are introduced. [[105]](#cite_note-105) Certain subjects are largely unique to the Waldorf schools. Foremost among these is [eurythmy](/wiki/Eurythmy), a movement art usually accompanying spoken texts or music which includes elements of drama and dance. [[78]](#cite_note-McDermott_etal-78) Although found in other educational contexts, cooking, [[106]](#cite_note-106) farming, [[107]](#cite_note-107) and [environmental](/wiki/Environmental_education) and [outdoor education](/wiki/Outdoor_education) [[108]](#cite_note-108) are centrally incorporated into Waldorf curriculum. Other differences include: non-competitive games and free play in younger years as opposed to athletics instruction; instruction in two foreign languages from the beginning of elementary school; and an experiential-phenomenological approach to science. [[109]](#cite_note-SSE-109) In this method, students observe and depict scientific concepts in their own words and drawings [[110]](#cite_note-110) rather than encountering the ideas first through a textbook. Science[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=10)] The scientific methodology of modern Waldorf schools utilizes a so-called "phenomenological approach" to science education employing a methodology of [inquiry-based learning](/wiki/Inquiry-based_learning) aiming to "strengthen the interest and ability to observe" in pupils. [[111]](#cite_note-PhenomScience-111): 111 Experts have called into question the quality of this phenomenological approach if it fails to educate Waldorf students on basic tenets of scientific fact. [[112]](#cite_note-112) The Waldorf approach is said to cultivate students with "high motivation" but "average achievement" in the sciences. [[113]](#cite_note-113) One study conducted by [California State University at Sacramento](/wiki/California_State_University,_Sacramento) researchers outlined numerous theories and ideas prevalent throughout Waldorf curricula that were patently [pseudoscientific](/wiki/Pseudoscience) and steeped in [magical thinking](/wiki/Magical_thinking). These included the idea that animals evolved from humans, that human spirits are physically incarnated into "soul qualities that manifested themselves into various animal forms", that the current geological formations on Earth have evolved through so-called "Lemurian" and "Atlantiean" epochs, and that the four kingdoms of nature are "mineral, plant, animal, and man". All of these are directly contradicted by mainstream scientific knowledge and have no basis in any form of conventional scientific study. Contradictory notions found in Waldorf textbooks are distinct from factual inaccuracies occasionally found in modern public school textbooks, as the inaccuracies in the latter are of a specific and minute nature that results from the progress of science. The inaccuracies present in Waldorf textbooks, however, are the result of a mode of thinking that has no valid basis in reason or logic. [[114]](#cite_note-114) This unscientific foundation has been blamed for the scarcity of systematic empirical research on Waldorf education as academic researchers hesitate in getting involved in studies of Waldorf schools lest it hamper their future career. [[115]](#cite_note-115) One study of science curriculum compared a group of American Waldorf school students to American public school students on three different test variables. [[111]](#cite_note-PhenomScience-111) Two tests measured verbal and non-verbal logical reasoning and the third was an international [TIMSS](/wiki/Trends_in_International_Mathematics_and_Science_Study) test. The TIMSS test covered scientific understanding of [magnetism](/wiki/Magnetism). The researchers found that Waldorf school students scored higher than both the public school students and the national average on the TIMSS test while scoring the same as public school students on the logical reasoning tests. [[111]](#cite_note-PhenomScience-111) However, when the logical reasoning tests measured students' understanding of part-to-whole relations, the Waldorf students also outperformed the public school students. [[111]](#cite_note-PhenomScience-111) The authors of the study noted the Waldorf students' enthusiasm for science, but viewed the science curriculum as "somewhat old-fashioned and out of date, as well as including some doubtful scientific material". [[111]](#cite_note-PhenomScience-111) In 2008, [Stockholm University](/wiki/Stockholm_University) terminated its Waldorf teacher training courses. In a statement, the university said "the courses did not encompass sufficient subject theory and a large part of the subject theory that is included is not founded on any scientific base". The dean, Stefan Nordlund, stated "the syllabus contains literature which conveys scientific inaccuracies that are worse than woolly; they are downright dangerous". [[116]](#cite_note-116) Information technology[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=11)] Because they view human interaction as the essential basis for younger children's learning and growth, [[79]](#cite_note-Ashley-79): 212 Waldorf schools view [computers](/wiki/Computer_science) as being first useful to children in the early teen years, after they have mastered "fundamental, time-honoured ways of discovering information and learning, such as practical experiments and books". [[117]](#cite_note-117) In the United Kingdom, Waldorf schools are granted an exemption by the [Department for Education](/wiki/Department_for_Education) (DfE) from the requirement to teach [ICT](/wiki/Information_and_communications_technology) as part of [Foundation Stage](/wiki/Foundation_Stage) education (ages 3-5). [[67]](#cite_note-Siraj-BlatchfordWhitebread2003-67) Waldorf schools have been popular with some parents working in the technology sector in the United States, including those from some of the most advanced technology firms. [[118]](#cite_note-118) [[119]](#cite_note-119) [[120]](#cite_note-120) [[121]](#cite_note-121) A number of technologically oriented parents from one school expressed their conviction that younger students do not need the exposure to computers and technology, but benefit from creative aspects of the education; one Google executive was quoted as saying "I fundamentally reject the notion you need technology aids in grammar school." [[122]](#cite_note-Richtel-122) Spirituality[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=12)] Waldorf education aims to educate children about a wide range of religious traditions without favoring any single tradition. [[78]](#cite_note-McDermott_etal-78) One of Steiner's primary aims was to establish a spiritual yet nondenominational setting for children from all backgrounds [[75]](#cite_note-Nielsen2004-75): 79 [[98]](#cite_note-Krogh-98) [[123]](#cite_note-oberski-123) that recognized the value of role models drawn from a wide range of literary and historical traditions in developing children's fantasy and moral imaginations. [[53]](#cite_note-Ullrich-53): 78 For Steiner, education was an activity which fosters the human being's connection to the divine and is thus inherently religious. [[124]](#cite_note-zander2007-124): 1422, 1430 Waldorf schools were historically "Christian based and [theistically](/wiki/Theism) oriented", [[77]](#cite_note-FE-77) as they expand into different cultural settings they are adapting to "a truly pluralistic spirituality". [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 146 Waldorf theories and practices are often modified from their European and Christian roots to meet the historical and cultural traditions of the local community. [[125]](#cite_note-WholeChild-125) Examples include Waldorf schools in Israel and Japan, which celebrate festivals drawn from these cultures, and classes in the Milwaukee Urban Waldorf school, which have adopted African American and Native American traditions. [[78]](#cite_note-McDermott_etal-78) Religion classes are typically absent from United States Waldorf schools, [[126]](#cite_note-126) but are mandatory in some German federal states, which require teachers who identify with each offered religion to teach such classes in addition to a nondenominational offering. In the United Kingdom, public Waldorf schools are not categorized as " [Faith schools](/wiki/Faith_schools)". [[127]](#cite_note-127) Teacher education[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=13)] Waldorf teacher education programs offer courses in [child development](/wiki/Child_development), the methodology of Waldorf teaching, academic subjects appropriate to the future teachers' chosen specialty, and the study of pedagogical texts and other works by Steiner. [[2]](#cite_note-Zdrazil2018-2) [[128]](#cite_note-scott-128) [[129]](#cite_note-oberski2-129) For early childhood and elementary school teachers, the training includes considerable artistic work in storytelling, movement, painting, music, and handwork. [[130]](#cite_note-Gidseg-130) Waldorf teacher education includes social-emotional development as "an integral and central element", which is unusual for teacher trainings. [[131]](#cite_note-MKP-131) A 2010 study found that students in advanced years of Waldorf teacher training courses scored significantly higher than students in non-Waldorf teacher trainings on three measures of empathy: perspective taking, empathic concern, and fantasy. [[131]](#cite_note-MKP-131) Governance[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=14)] Independent schools[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=15)] One of Waldorf education's central premises is that all educational and cultural institutions should be [self-governing](/wiki/Self-governance) and should grant teachers a high degree of creative autonomy within the school; [[132]](#cite_note-132): 143 [[77]](#cite_note-FE-77) this is based upon the conviction that a holistic approach to education aiming at the development of free individuals can only be successful when based on a school form that expresses these same principles. [[133]](#cite_note-Willmann-133) Most Waldorf schools are not directed by a [principal](/wiki/Principal_(school)) or head teacher, but rather by a number of groups, including: - The college of teachers, who decide on pedagogical issues, normally on the basis of consensus. This group is usually open to full-time teachers who have been with the school for a prescribed period of time. Each school is accordingly unique in its approach, as it may act solely on the basis of the decisions of the college of teachers to set policy or other actions pertaining to the school and its students. [[69]](#cite_note-IO-69) - The board of trustees, who decide on governance issues, especially those relating to school finances and legal issues, including formulating strategic plans and central policies. [[134]](#cite_note-134) There are coordinating bodies for Waldorf education at both the national (e.g. the Association of Waldorf Schools of North America and the Steiner Waldorf Schools Fellowship in the UK and Ireland) and international level (e.g. International Association for Waldorf Education and The European Council for Steiner Waldorf Education (ECSWE)). These organizations certify the use of the registered names "Waldorf" and "Steiner school" and offer accreditations, often in conjunction with regional independent school associations. [[135]](#cite_note-135) State-funded schools[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=16)] Independent schools receive complete or partial funding in much of Europe, particularly in Northern and Eastern Europe. Sweden, Finland, Holland, and Slovakia provide over 90% of independent schools' funding, while Slovenia, Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg, Ireland, Hungary, Estonia, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Spain, and Portugal provide the majority of independent schools' funding. [[136]](#cite_note-136) In countries outside of this region, funding for independent schools varies widely. Homeschooling[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=17)] Waldorf-inspired [home schools](/wiki/Homeschooling) typically obtain their program information through informal parent groups, online, or by purchasing a curriculum. Waldorf homeschooling groups are not affiliated with the Association of Waldorf Schools of North America (AWSNA), which represents independent schools and it is unknown how many home schools use a Waldorf-inspired curriculum. Educationalist Sandra Chistolini suggests that parents offer their children Waldorf-inspired homeschooling because "the frustration and boredom some children feel in school are eliminated and replaced with constant attention to the needs of childhood [and] connections between content and the real world". [[137]](#cite_note-137) Regional differences[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=18)] Some Waldorf schools in English-speaking countries have met opposition due to [vaccine hesitancy](/wiki/Vaccine_controversies) among parents. [[138]](#cite_note-138) In a 2011 article, Waldorf schools were identified as a risk factor for noncompliance of Measles vaccination. [[139]](#cite_note-139) Other controversies have centered on Waldorf schools' educational standards and the mystical and antiquated nature of some of Steiner's theories. [[140]](#cite_note-SupremeCourtReview-140) [[141]](#cite_note-141) [[142]](#cite_note-142) [[143]](#cite_note-143) United States[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=19)] The first US Waldorf-inspired public school, the Yuba River Charter School in California, opened in 1994. The Waldorf public school movement is currently expanding rapidly; while in 2010, there were twelve Waldorf-inspired public schools in the United States, [[144]](#cite_note-Pap-144) by 2018 there were 53 such schools. One study found that students at Waldorf-inspired schools watch less television and spend more time engaging in creative activities or spending time with friends. [[157]](#cite_note-Moscow-157) Social engagement[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=23)] Steiner's belief that all people are imbued with a spiritual core has fueled Waldorf schools' social mission. [[158]](#cite_note-Hayes-158) The schools have always been coeducational and open to children of all social classes. They were designed from the beginning to be [comprehensive](/wiki/Comprehensive_schools), 12-year schools under the direction of their own teachers, rather than the state or other external authorities, [[159]](#cite_note-EAE-159) all radical principles when Steiner first articulated them. [[160]](#cite_note-AEA-160) Social renewal and transformation remain primary goals for Waldorf schools, [[161]](#cite_note-PhillipsB-161) which seek to cultivate pupils' sense of social responsibility. [[63]](#cite_note-Edwards-63) [[162]](#cite_note-162) [[163]](#cite_note-163) [[164]](#cite_note-164) Studies suggest that this is successful; [[53]](#cite_note-Ullrich-53): 190 [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 4 Waldorf pupils have been found to be more interested in and engaged with social and moral questions and to have more positive attitudes than students from mainstream schools, [[165]](#cite_note-165) demonstrating activism and self-confidence and feeling empowered to forge their own futures. [[166]](#cite_note-166) Waldorf schools build close learning communities, founded on the shared values of its members, [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 17 in ways that can lead to transformative learning experiences that allow all participants, including parents, to become more aware of their own individual path, [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 5, 17, 32, 40 [[85]](#cite_note-Stehlik-85): 238 but which at times also risk becoming exclusive. [[53]](#cite_note-Ullrich-53): 167, 207 Reports from small-scale studies suggest that there are lower levels of harassment and bullying in Waldorf schools [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 29 and that European Waldorf students have much lower rates of [xenophobia](/wiki/Xenophobia) and [gender stereotypes](/wiki/Gender_stereotypes) than students in any other type of schools. Reception[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=25)] Evaluations of students' progress[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=26)] Although studies about Waldorf education tend to be small-scale and vary in national context, a 2005 independent comprehensive review of the literature concluded there was evidence that Waldorf education encourages academic achievement as well as "creative, social and other capabilities important to the holistic growth of a person". [[55]](#cite_note-Woods-55): 39 [[79]](#cite_note-Ashley-79) In comparison to state school pupils, European Waldorf students are significantly more enthusiastic about learning, report having more fun and being less bored in school, view their school environments as pleasant and supportive places where they are able to discover their personal academic strengths, [[184]](#cite_note-Welt2012-184) and have more positive views of the future. [[185]](#cite_note-JGidley-185) Twice as many European Waldorf students as state school pupils report having good relationships with teachers; they also report significantly fewer ailments such as headaches, stomach aches, and disrupted sleep. [[184]](#cite_note-Welt2012-184) A 2007 German study found that an above-average number of Waldorf students become teachers, doctors, engineers, scholars of the humanities, and scientists. [[186]](#cite_note-Jimenez-186) Studies of Waldorf students' artistic capacities found that they averaged higher scores on the [Torrance Test of Creative Thinking Ability](/wiki/Torrance_Tests_of_Creative_Thinking), [[187]](#cite_note-187) drew more accurate, detailed, and imaginative drawings, [[188]](#cite_note-188) and were able to develop richer images than comparison groups. [[185]](#cite_note-JGidley-185) Some observers have noted that Waldorf educators tend to be more concerned to address the needs of weaker students who need support than they are to meet the needs of talented students who could benefit from advanced work. [[189]](#cite_note-189) Educational scholars[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&action=edit§ion=27)] Professor of educational psychology [Clifford Mayes](/wiki/Clifford_Mayes) said "Waldorf students learn in sequences and paces that are developmentally appropriate, aesthetically stimulating, emotionally supportive, and ecologically sensitive." [[190]](#cite_note-190) Professors of education Timothy Leonard and Peter Willis stated that Waldorf education "cultivates the imagination of the young to provide them a firm emotional foundation upon which to build a sound intellectual life". [[15]](#cite_note-Uhr-15): 382, 401 Thomas Nielsen, assistant professor at the [University of Canberra](/wiki/University_of_Canberra)'s education department, said that imaginative teaching approaches used in Waldorf education (drama, exploration, storytelling, routine, arts, discussion and empathy) are effective stimulators of spiritual-aesthetic, intellectual and physical development, expanding "the concept of holistic and imaginative education" and recommends these to mainstream educators.
